Project Number: 43522 
Cluster—Regional—Capacity Development Technical Assistance (C–R–CDTA)

Solar Energy Development in South Asia 
 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

Vice-President  X. Zhao, Operations 1 
Director General  K. Senga, South Asia Department (SARD)  
Director  T. Kandiah, Energy Division, SARD 
   
Team leader  L. George, Energy Specialist, SARD 
Team members  N. Sakai, Senior Climate Change Specialist, SARD 
  
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Affordable and sustainable energy services using renewable energy are among the 
essential  ingredients  of  low-carbon  economic  development.  The  international  community 
emphasizes the importance of technology for sustainable development and for meeting climate 
change challenges in a reasonable time frame, both in developed and developing countries.  
 
2.  Strategy 2020 of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) states (i) ADB will strengthen the 
focus of its operations on the environment to realize environmentally sustainable growth for the 
region; (ii) ADB will expand promotion of and investment in sound environmental management, 
while  simultaneously  capitalizing  on  the  strengths  of  its  operations,  such  as  infrastructure 
development and finance; and (iii) in its programs, policies, and strategies, ADB will emphasize 
climate change aspects where it could help developing member countries (DMCs) move their 
economies to low-carbon growth paths, by, among others, expanding the use of clean energy 
sources.1 
 
3.  The  Energy  Policy,  2009  recognizes  ADB's  role  in  developing  renewable  energy, 
facilitating  wider  deployment  of  technologies  by  raising  awareness,  promoting  policy  and 
regulatory incentives to encourage their use, and promoting financing packages that share risks 
and  lower  cost.2 The  policy  states  that  ADB  will  support  technology  transfer  for  cleaner 
technologies in the DMCs through demonstration projects. For South Asian DMCs, solar energy 
compares favorably with other common renewable energy sources, such as wind and small 
hydropower. In addition, the modular nature of the technology and relative ease of installation in 
inhabited areas are considered beneficial. In this context, ADB notes the need to (i) identify key 
solar energy technologies relevant to South Asian DMCs and potential opportunities for end-use 
applications for these technologies, and (ii) develop an enabling environment for the deployment 
of these technologies. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
4.  Deployment of solar technologies. Solar energy technologies are increasingly being 
considered an important element for sustainable development and to address climate change 
concerns.  The  worldwide  capacity  of  one  form  of  solar  energy  technology,  namely  grid-
connected solar photovoltaic generators, reached 13 gigawatts in 2008 (an increase of 70% 
compared to the previous year).3 Of particular relevance to the South Asian DMC context is the 
fact that solar energy could assist in addressing multiple imperatives such as energy security, 
electrification in remote areas, employment generation, provision of resilient livelihoods; and 
could potentially drive inclusive economic growth in remote areas.   
 
5.  Solar power generation technologies can broadly be categorized into (i) large power 
plants using concentrated solar power and solar photovoltaic technologies, (ii) small power 
plants based on distributed on-grid or off-grid solar photovoltaic systems. In addition, associated 
technologies are being developed for grid management (to enable stable and measurable two-
way power supply) and power storage (e.g., using lithium-ion batteries).

Manila. 
2  ADB. 2009. Energy Policy. Manila. 
3  In  addition,  grid-connected  solar  photovoltaic  has  been  identified  as  the  fastest-growing  power  generation 
technology worldwide with a six-fold increase in global capacity since 2004. Renewable Energy Policy Network for 
the 21st Century (REN21). 2009. Renewables Global Status Report: 2009 Update. Paris: REN21 Secretariat.

2 
 
6.  Deployment of solar and associated technologies in the DMCs is particularly important 
because (i) the learning curve and scale of production effects based on increased demand from 
emerging markets could cause production costs to converge toward grid parity pricing, and (ii) 
some DMCs are in a more advantageous position compared with developed countries in terms 
of,  for  example,  higher  solar  radiation,  more  rapidly  growing  electricity  demand,  and  land 
availability.4 As a result, the DMCs could play a pivotal role as global and regional technology 
hubs for manufacturing solar technology related goods and equipment that could significantly 
bolster solar-based power generation capacity with its implications for sustainable economic 
growth.         
 
7.  Most of the DMCs, particularly in South Asia, lag in the development and deployment of 
solar energy technologies, partly because of perceptions of high costs, but also importantly 
because of (i) limited access to the latest technology and knowledge in the area, (ii) institutional 
capacity constraints among stakeholders to further solar energy-related developments, and 
(iii) lack of government formulation or implementation of an appropriate policy and regulatory 
framework in most DMCs to encourage offtake from solar energy sources. In addition, most of 
the global private sector focus is presently concentrated in developed country markets in terms 
of financial resources and human expertise. As a result, despite attractive factors including the 
size of the potential market and the beneficial impact of deploying solar-based technologies in 
such  markets,  international  developers  and  equipment  suppliers  tend  to  be  reluctant  to 
participate in the development of large-scale solar photovoltaic and concentrated solar power 
projects in the emerging DMCs. 
 
8.  Several South Asian DMCs have implemented small-scale pilot solar photovoltaic and 
solar home systems to provide electrification especially in remote areas. While several such 
systems are successfully deployed, there are concerns related to the cost of deployment and 
the sustainability of operations. Support will be required for the following activities: (i) research 
and development support to reduce the cost of local component manufacturing, assembly, and 
deployment; (ii) development of a policy framework to ensure appropriate links with existing 
remote area electrification policies and promotion of appropriate system sizes and technologies 
(including  through  subsidy  intervention  and  fiscal  incentives)  especially  to  disadvantaged 
households with no access to alternate clean energy sources; (iii) capacity development through 
training for maintenance of solar energy systems in remote areas; and (iv) innovative financing 
mechanisms  and  institutional  support  for  household  electrification  and  community  income 
generation through solar energy systems. ADB could support South Asian DMCs on these 
issues through sharing of knowledge and best practices from other similarly placed countries in 
these areas. 
 
9.  Climate change adaptation. The South Asian DMCs have initiated measures to cope 
with climate change. Several countries have developed their initial climate change action plans 
and constituted institutional mechanisms to focus on climate change. Strategy 2020 states that 
ADB  will  help  DMCs  adapt  to  the  unavoidable  impacts  of  climate  change.  From  a  solar 
development perspective, ADB could support the usage of solar energy-based systems to serve 
as an early warning system for events such as glacial melting; sea-level rise; and other extreme 
weather events such as floods, and changes in rainfall and cropping patterns; and for coping 
                                                 
4  There is scope for further reducing the cost of energy from renewable sources by developing more appropriate

systems to address environmental, health, and disaster management-related incidents arising 
from such events. 
 
10.  Coordination with other agencies. While ADB and other development partners have 
provided assistance for rural electrification using solar energy, these instances tend to be 
isolated  and  have  few  opportunities  to  share  knowledge  and  disseminate  best  practices, 
particularly beyond a country or region. As a result, a solar divide could result, where developing 
countries may not receive adequate benefit of environment-friendly technology-driven economic 
growth.  
 
11.  Therefore,  ADB  aims  to  provide  integrated  and  collective  support  to  the  DMCs  to 
develop  and  deploy  solar  power  generation  and  the  synergized  technologies  through  
(i) communication to identify opportunities for solar energy development among participating 
South Asian DMCs, (ii) knowledge sharing on best practices for solar energy development,  
(iii) development of solar energy projects based on the lessons from past efforts of ADB and 
other development partners, and (iv) a collective capacity development program. From this 
perspective, ADB setup a solar technology team under the energy community of practice in 
October 2010 to begin work on a road map for integrated solar energy development. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
12.  The  cluster  regional  technical  assistance  (TA)  aims  to  promote  solar  energy 
development  among  participating  South  Asian  DMCs.  It  will  contribute  to  an  advanced 
understanding of opportunities for solar energy development in the region, actions required to 
accelerate institutional and business models for development and deployment of solar energy, 
and mechanisms to promote technology transfer to developing countries and to enhance the 
scope for cooperation on research and development. DMCs’ experiences in other regions will 
be  shared  in  cooperation  with  ADB’s  regional  departments.  The  design  and  monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1.5 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
13.  The impact of the TA will be the development of a sustainable solar energy sector in 
South Asia to support inclusive and low carbon economic growth. The outcome will be to create 
an enabling environment for the development of solar projects among South Asian DMCs.   
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
14.  The TA uses a cluster approach. Subproject 1 includes an opportunity assessment and 
capacity development activities for South Asian DMC representatives. Seven key areas were 
identified for subsequent subprojects; specific actions will be worked out during the course of TA 
implementation.  Coordination  with  other  development  partners  will  be  undertaken  to  avoid 
duplication with other projects.  
 
15.  Subproject 1: Opportunity assessment. As an initial step, an opportunity assessment 
for solar energy development in South Asian DMCs will be undertaken to identify the enabling 
requirements for (i) a policy and regulatory framework; (ii) industry development; (iii) project 
development; and (iv) research and development with an objective to (a) promote private sector 
participation,  (b)  facilitate  technology  transfer,  (c) enhance  knowledge  sharing,  and  (d) 
                                                 
5  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 27 November 2009.

4 
 
strengthen institutional capacities of relevant stakeholders. In parallel, past projects in this 
subsector supported by ADB and other development partners will be analyzed and a summary 
of lessons and relevant best practices collated. During the opportunity assessment, interviews 
will  be  conducted  with  various  stakeholders,  in  particular,  international  private  investors, 
financing agencies, developers, utilities, consumers, equipment suppliers, and manufacturers.  
 
16.  Subsequently,  a  workshop  will  be  held  to  share  the  findings  of  the  opportunity 
assessment  with  the  government,  regulatory  agencies,  and  knowledge  institutions  among 
participating  DMCs  in  South  Asia.  In  addition,  the  workshop  will  invite,  among  others, 
development  partners,  international  and  domestic  financiers,  investors,  developers, 
manufacturers, and suppliers with expertise in concentrated solar power and solar photovoltaic 
project  development,  and  associated  technologies  such  as  grid  management  and  battery 
manufacturing. Resource persons with expertise in solar energy development will be invited to 
the  workshop  to  share  best  practices  from  other  countries.  The  workshop  will  discuss 
opportunities, constraints, and possible road map for solar energy development in the DMCs to 
raise the awareness of stakeholders with regard to (i) appropriate technologies; (ii) gaps in 
policy  and  regulatory  frameworks,  research  and  development,  project  development,  and 
industry development; and (iii) potential action plans for the way forward.  
 
17.  In particular, the workshop will (i) discuss how to develop commercially viable large-
scale  and  distributed  concentrated  solar  power  and  solar  photovoltaic  projects  in  DMCs 
involving the private sector, (ii) assess past initiatives for off-grid electrification projects with 
solar energy, (iii) identify lessons and best practices from other countries that have deployed 
solar technologies, and (iv) discuss options for subsequent subprojects. The outcome of the 
workshop will be summarized in a report to be published and posted on the ADB website. Other 
follow-up action including identification of future subprojects will be undertaken.  
 
18.   Subsequent subprojects. Support will be provided to the participating South Asian 
DMCs for the following potential subprojects.  
 
(i)   Policy  and  regulatory  framework  development  and  implementation. 
Assistance  will  be  provided  to  develop  and  implement  solar  energy-related 
policies as well as transparent and stable regulatory frameworks that support the 
private sector (investors, developers, manufacturers, and suppliers) as well as 
other  relevant  stakeholders,  such  as  consumers,  local  community,  and 
nongovernment organizations, on issues relating to solar energy and associated 
technology development.  
 
(ii)   Institutional  capacity  development  for  solar  energy  development. 
Assistance will be provided for institutional capacity development of regulators, 
government  officials,  private  sector  (such  as  domestic  developers, 
manufacturers, and suppliers), consumers, local communities, nongovernment 
organizations, and utilities on issues relating to solar energy and associated 
technology development.    
 
(iii)   Solar project feasibility study. Assistance to DMCs to conduct solar mapping 
studies  and  other  prefeasibility  works  to  develop  solar  photovoltaic  and 
concentrated solar power projects will be provided. Assistance for solar energy 
projects in areas such as special economic zones may also be included.

5 
(iv)   Rural electrification using solar energy. Assistance to DMCs to develop and 
implement business models for solar energy utilization and income generation on 
an off-grid or mini-grid basis will be undertaken.  
 
(v)   Grid impact studies. Conceptualization of relevant smart grid and smart mini-
grid systems will be line with the DMC’s environment, e.g., net-metering, current 
and voltage control, and battery deployment at substations. It could also include 
studies to assess the impact of renewable energy on the grid. The studies could 
be a basis for project preparation of future transmission and distribution projects 
or capacity development programs for transmission and distribution utilities.  
 
(vi)   Innovative financing mechanisms. Development of various forms of financing, 
risk mitigation, and financing models will make solar projects financially and 
economically viable—aiming to reduce capital costs, mitigate risks, and enhance 
financial viability for solar energy and associated technologies in DMCs, including 
mobilizing grant assistance, creating funds, activating programmatic  supports 
from mechanisms such as the Clean Development Mechanism carbon credits, 
and securing regulatory incentives.  
 
(vii)   Application to adaptation efforts. Assistance to South Asian DMCs to apply 
solar  power  for  climate  change  adaptation-related  activities,  such  as  for 
development  of  systems  for  early  warning  and  disaster  management  in 
ecologically sensitive areas (e.g. glaciers and islands) will be considered.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
19.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,400,000; subproject 1 is estimated to cost $540,000. The 
TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB's Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF— 
other sources). Details are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
20.  ADB will be the executing agency for this TA. The South Asia Department will work in 
close  coordination  with  the  Regional  and  Sustainable  Development  Department  and  other 
operations departments on the TA. Each participating DMC may designate an existing agency 
as the focal point or the implementing agency for each subproject under the TA. Consultants will 
be chosen for subproject 1 at TA startup. Consulting services for subsequent subprojects (e.g., 
prefeasibility studies, policy and regulatory review and implementation, institutional capacity 
building) will be chosen during TA implementation depending on discussions with participating 
South Asian DMCs. 
 
21.  Subproject  1  will  require  one  international  consultant  for  6  person-months  (on  an 
intermittent basis) and one national consultant for 3 person-months to develop an opportunity 
assessment paper for solar energy development, conduct a workshop, and select potential 
activities  for  subsequent  subprojects.  Both  the  consultants  will  be  recruited  as  individual 
consultants. The consultants will be engaged in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use 
of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). Disbursements under the TA will be made 
in accordance with ADB's Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook.6 Equipment turnover 
and disposal to the implementing agencies or DMC governments will be undertaken upon 
                                                 
6  ADB. 2008. Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook. Manila.

6 
 
completion of TA according to ADB guidelines. The consultants’ terms of reference are in 
Appendix 3. Activities funded by this TA will start in a DMC only after ADB has received a “no-
objection” in writing from the relevant government. The TA is expected to be implemented from 
January 2010 to December 2012. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,400,000 on a grant basis 
for Solar Energy Development in South Asia, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS (SUBPROJECT 1) 
 
1.   The consulting team comprising one international consultant and one national consultant 
will  (i)  conduct  an  opportunity  assessment  for  solar  energy  development  in  South  Asian 
developing  member  countries  (DMCs),  (ii) hold  a  workshop  for  solar  energy  development,  
iii) identify and assist in monitoring future subprojects, and (iv) disseminate the outcome of the 
technical assistance (TA).   
 
2.   Subproject 1 will require 6 person-months of international consulting services (on an 
intermittent basis) and 3 person-months of national consulting services. Both the consultants will 
be recruited as individual consultants. The consultants will be engaged in accordance with the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from 
time to time). The TA is expected to be implemented from January 2010 to December 2012. 
 
3.   The international solar business development specialist will be the team leader. The 
consultant team will identify the enabling requirements for solar energy development with a view 
to promoting private sector participation, facilitating technology transfer, enhancing knowledge 
sharing, and strengthening institutional capacities of relevant stakeholders. The international 
consultant will submit a report of the TA outcome and recommend action plans. The national 
consultant will provide logistic support for the workshop and other relevant work.       
 
A.   Scope of Work 
 
4.   Subproject 1 is expected to be implemented from January 2010 to December 2012. 
However, the work should be concentrated within the first 5 months. The professional positions, 
person-months, and activities for the required positions are as follows. 
 
5.   Solar energy development specialist (international, team leader, 6 person-months). 
The activities of this position include the following: 
 
(i)  Opportunity assessment for solar energy development. The specialist will 
 
(a)  develop an opportunity assessment paper for solar energy development 
in South Asian DMCs covering policy and regulatory framework, industry 
development, project development, and research and development with 
objectives  to  promote  private  sector  participation,  facilitate  technology 
transfer,  enhance  knowledge  sharing,  and  strengthen  institutional 
capacities of the relevant stakeholders; 
(b)  review lessons and best practices for solar energy development in other 
regions in reference to the framework (item a); 
(c)  review  past  and  ongoing  assistance  programs  for  solar  energy 
development undertaken by development partners in the context of items 
(a) and (b), and analyze the gaps and potential for collaboration with ADB 
in this area; and 
(d)  conduct interviews through videoconferencing, teleconferencing, or face-
to-face meetings with relevant stakeholders including international private 
investors,  financiers,  developers,  manufacturers,  equipment  suppliers, 
funding  agencies,  knowledge  institutions,  and  government  officials  in 
DMCs to understand the opportunities and note the constraints regarding 
development of the solar energy market in South Asian DMCs.

Appendix 3  11 
(ii)  Workshop on solar energy development. The specialist will 
 
(a)  develop  the  detailed  agenda  and  schedule  of  the  workshop  in  close 
consultation with ADB, participating South Asian DMCs, the private sector, 
and other relevant stakeholders; 
(b)  engage  distinguished  experts  and  development  practitioners  as 
participants and for the preparation of technical papers and presentations 
related to the themes of the workshop; 
(c)  nominate  workshop  participants  from  international  private  sector, 
knowledge institutions and other relevant people, and facilitate invitations; 
and 
(d)  facilitate the workshop and provide guidance to the national workshop 
management specialist on logistics, documentation, secretariat services, 
dissemination of information and materials, and related support. 
 
(iii)  Subproject selection in South Asian DMCs. The specialist will 
 
(a)  review alternate options for the selection of appropriate subprojects to be 
supported by ADB subsequently; and 
(b)  review and monitor future subprojects. 
 
(iv)  Others. The specialist will 
 
(a)  as TA leader, coordinate TA implementation and ensure timely delivery of 
all tasks by team members; 
(b)  produce  outcomes  in  the  form  of  high-quality  publications, 
recommendations, and documentation relevant to operations of ADB and 
its DMCs; 
(c)  participate in key ADB events as a resource speaker; 
(d)  generate and disseminate knowledge on sustainable development issues 
and approaches of most relevance to South Asia; and 
(e)  provide  general  guidance  to  ADB  on  ways  to  achieve  its  strategic 
objectives in solar energy development. 
 
6.   Workshop management specialist (national, 3 person-months). Activities include the 
following: 
(i)  support  the  team  leader  in  facilitating  the  workshop,  including  logistics, 
documentation, secretariat services, dissemination of information and materials, 
and related support; 
(ii)  reimburse selected participants for travel, hotel, per diem, and incidentals;  
(iii)  conduct  financing  arrangements  for  the  preparation  of  technical  papers  and 
postworkshop publications; and 
(iv)  help  the  team  leader  conduct  follow-up  activities  including  publication  and 
posting on the ADB website. 
 
B.   Reporting Requirements 
7.   In May 2010 the consulting team will conduct a workshop on solar energy development 
with participation of representatives from government, solar energy nodal agencies of South 
Asian DMCs, international and national private sector, utilities, and other identified stakeholders.

12  Appendix 3  
8.   The following reports will be produced at key stages of TA implementation: 
 
(i)  an inception report within 1 calendar month of TA commencement;  
(ii)  an interim report with the draft opportunity assessment paper and feedback from 
various stakeholders within 2 calendar months of TA commencement; 
(iii)  a draft final report within 2 weeks of the workshop incorporating knowledge 
disseminated during the workshop and views expressed by participants during 
the interactions; and 
(iv)  a final report at the end of the fifth calendar month following TA commencement 
and following incorporation of all the comments received. 
 
9.   The consultants will submit five copies of each report, and three digital copies of the final 
version of each report on CD-ROM to ADB in English.
